Replace.Text: +30%[icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production from being the Silla's associated Wonder.

The Three Kingdoms of Korea were a set of culturally similar states on the peninsula in the first millennium CE. Of these, Silla was both the oldest and the most distant from Chinese influence, but each of the Three Kingdoms shared a militarized society and centralized system of government with a powerful monarch and aristocracy. In the early years of the Three Kingdoms, each power sought to balance the others through selective alliances and well-timed advances.

In this early Silla period, the system of “bone rank,” wherein all members of society had a particular position owing to their lineage, led to a hierarchical aristocracy with a king or queen at the top. While Buddhism had made inroads into the Three Kingdoms, Silla was the most traditional of the realms and kept Korean shamanic traditions at its core.

But at the edges of the map, there were always other powers. Silla allied with the Tang dynasty of China and subjugated the other two kingdoms in the seventh century CE. But Tang assistance came at a cost – the Tang sought to establish Chinese colonies throughout Korea, and Silla soon found itself fighting alongside its former rivals to expel these incursions.

Having unified the peninsula, Silla faced the task of keeping it. An early step was the reinforcement of royal absolutism, extending out from the capital, now named Seorabeol (“capital,” a word shortened in later years to “Seoul,” though the present-day city is not the same as the Silla capital). The Council of Nobles had its authority dramatically cut, and land became tied to a person’s position vis-à-vis the capital, not their family; thus maintaining one’s position involved placating the center. Branches of the family tree that had become distant from the capital found their authority – and income – whittled away, building seething resentment.

Silla society was also organized around trade, especially of silk. Trade was important in Silla, both as a political tool as well as for income. The Silk Road clearly linked Silla along with its other sites – a Byzantine hairpin could travel from Constantinople to Silla in a mere six months, and Muslim scholars and even an exiled Iranian prince lived and studied in Silla. Indeed, Islam makes its first appearance in Korea during Silla, though it was to wane afterwards.

But there were cracks forming. The suppression of local nobles could work in a truly isolated place, but when these nobles began to grow rich on trade, they gained power that they used to challenge the central state. Riven by civil war, in the 10th century CE, Silla surrendered to the state of Goryeo.

Buddhism arrived in Korea around the 4th century CE, and became a significant political tool – and point of contention – for Silla. Korean animism, focused around the worship of clan deities, had been central to the cultivation of elite power. But powerful noble families are an impediment to a centralized monarchy, which seeks the supremacy of one family over all – thus, monarchs of Silla adopted Buddhist religion, and sponsored the construction of massive temples – sachal, in Korean - within the capital.

The most significant of these was the Dragon Temple, Hwangnyonsa. This was a large nine-tiered pagoda, the largest building in East Asia at the time. From Hwangnyonsa, a new, royal-directed Buddhism was administered and promulgated throughout the kingdom. Buddhism remained contentious in Korea owing to its association with royalty, most notably being suppressed during later Joseon in favor of Confucianism and its class of scholar-administrators.

Korean temple architecture featured independent buildings with different functions – halls for monks to eat and sleep, halls for particular images, and, of course, the lecture hall, where monks would study the sutras. While lecture halls are often not the most dramatic structures within a temple, they serve a crucial purpose. The development and study of Buddhism was a hallmark of Silla – the new religion was precariously situated between the monarchies, who embraced it as a source of international legitimacy, and the nobility, who rejected it as a threat to their ancient rights.

The pagoda is the central feature of most Buddhist temples. It houses the most sacred objects that the temple possesses: relics of the Buddha or famous monks, and other treasures. The pagoda of the Dragon Temple was especially outstanding. It was a wooden structure reported to be over 250 feet tall, making it the tallest structure in East Asia and the tallest wooden structure in the world at the time. Today, only the foundation stones remain, though they, too, are formidable.

The “bone-rank system” of Silla, kolp’um served to place each member of Silla society into a hierarchical rank. These ranks determined who was eligible for kingship and who could hold an official title, as well as who was barred from these positions. After Silla’s expansion, the system also solidified the capital’s hold upon the provinces, as provincial residents – even those of formerly noble stock – were ineligible to participate in the Silla administration.

The Samguk Sagi is the “History of the Three Kingdoms” of Korea, an account of the tensions between Silla, Goguryeo, and Baekje. It was compiled later, in the Goryeo era, but became a basis for much of the knowledge about this time period: lists of rulers, battles, and conquests, and a description of the bureaucratic structure of the various polities.

The bone-rank system served to concretize power in Silla, making sure that centrally-connected families in their base in the capital held sway over the rest of the country. The highest of these ranks was the seonggol, the “sacred bone,” a designation that pointed to those eligible for kingship.
But this was a feature of early Silla. After the reign of Queen Jindeok, the seonggol system fell out of use.

The level in the bone-rank system under the seonggol, the “sacred bone,” the jingol (“true bone”) denoted official positions up to but not including the kingship. Here, too, families held onto their appointed place in a hierarchy. After the end of the seonggol system, the jingol system remained, and it was from these ranks that later Silla royalty came.

As Silla declined, those without such a rank often turned towards the new religions of Buddhism and Confucianism to rise in power, marking a shift in Korean society that would pave the way for Goryeo.

In Silla, the office of sangdaedeung was one of the highest ranks outside of the actual monarchy, and the highest of the jingol ranks (at least until the throne was opened to jingol). This official presided over the Hwabaek Council, and passed decisions on major matters affecting the kingdom.

The hwarang – a group of aristocratic youth bound together by a code of chivalry and emphasizing poetry and art as much as combat – have become a symbol of the romance and beauty of the Silla period well into the present day. A hwarang followed the sesok o-kye, the five commandments, emphasizing Confucian and Buddhist teachings, service to king and family, courage and loyalty to friends, and the wisdom of mercy.
The hwarang’s martial role diminished after the unification of Silla, and they largely disappeared from the historical record after Silla’s fall. They formally disbanded during Joseon.
Silla Unique Quarter. Created by constructing the Lecture Hall and Pagoda in the same District. +1 [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold for every Resource assigned to this City.
+1 [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold for every Resource assigned to this City.

+3 [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture. +1[icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture Adjacency for Wonders. Increases number of Resources that may be assigned to this Settlement by 1 if placed on Rough Terrain. Silla Unique Culture Building. Ageless.
[B]Effect:[/B] Increases number of Resources that may be assigned to this Settlement by 1 if placed on Rough Terrain.[N]Silla Unique Building.
+3 [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] Happiness. +1[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence Adjacency for Natural Wonders, Mountains, and Wonders. Silla Unique Happiness Building. Ageless.
"How brilliant is the autumn field, ripe with the fruit of enlightenment beneath the full moon."
"In the third month, a comet appeared in the southeast and a dragon flew past Mount Yangsan."
"It is no wonder that the founders of the Three Kingdoms had divine origins."
"Ah, Hwarang, you are the high pine branch that does not know frost."

When you form an alliance both players receive a free Trade Route from the other player's capital; these Trade Routes do not go away when the alliance ends and do not count against your Trade Route limit with this empire.
When you defeat an enemy Unit with a Hwarang, gain [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture equal to 25% of the defeated Unit's strength.
Increases number of Resources that may be assigned to Towns by 1.
+5 Land Trade Route Range to all Settlements.
+2 [icon:YIELD_HAPPINESS] Happiness on Resources in Towns with a Happiness building.
All Trade Routes between you and your allies award [icon:YIELD_FOOD] Food and [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION] Production equal to the route's [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold award.
+1[icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold and +1[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY] Influence on Resources assigned to Trade Outpost or Factory Towns.

The temple bell rings out across Korea, and Silla responds. In their palaces, the seonggol pursue a life of luxury, lending inspiration to the craftsman’s hands, the poet’s brush, and the soldier’s step. Guide Silla now, and bring an enlightened hand to a darkened world.
Rising above disorder, Silla emerges the first of the three kingdoms. With guile and grace, may it become the greatest.
Alliances are key to Silla's strategy, so keep those relationships friendly and manage your Influence wisely on Endeavors.
Contains a new Antiquity Age Civilization, Silla.
Your Alliance with {1_LeaderName} has ended. The free Trade Routes between your capitals have been removed.
Your Alliance with {1_LeaderName} grants you free Trade Routes between your capitals. Your previous Trade Route there has been cancelled and the Merchant who started it is now in your Capital.

A lord inspects the deed to a miniscule plot of land gifted to him by a noble. The noble smirks, expecting a grand display of appreciation for the insulting offer. Knowing he is lower in the hierarchy of bones, the lord is careful with his tongue.
The farmhands will be happy to have less work.
Much more land would have just gone to waste.

Wearing gold jewelry and smelling of ginseng, an aristocrat admires her acres of land. Across the horizon are fields tended by her neighbors, on plots granted to them by the royal family just like her. Property equals power, and the aristocrat wants for more.

A sea of adolescent men stand perfectly still, awaiting orders. Born from aristocracy, this new class of Hwarang uphold a chivalric oath to fight, protect, and spread their faith. The looming threat of an enemy army tests their combat readiness.

Accompanied by a crescendo of music, dancers move with each word sung by the writer. Every stanza is joined by a flourish of song and dance, expressing a story of hope. As she sings the final line, her voice booms and reverberates through the theater.

A foreign trader approaches the merchant's booth, eyeing several gold items for sale. The precious metals reflect off his skin, casting him in an ethereal glow. He must bring something magnificent back home to resell at his stall.
Golden accessories that show off beauty.
Golden belts that show off wealth.
Young stablehands tend to a pregnant mare. As they work on her hooves, a clap of thunder startles them all. The two men look up at the clear sky-- could this be a sign?
It signals a child was born to lead new discoveries.
It means a child was born who will usher in prosperity.

Times have changed, bringing a new way to put the dead to rest. Stamped with flowers and coated in a green glaze, a tiny urn waits to be finished in the kiln. A bell rings in the distance, signaling...
Monarchs and aristocrats clash as tensions rise over land claims and marriage prospects. As houses claw for power, common folk suffer at the hands of the rich.
Commoners work efficiently when given small comforts.
As upheaval ripples across Silla, little room is left for nuanced discussion. Disagreements about who should rule, and how, will only be resolved on the battlefield.
A firm hand can quash any uprising.
These are the mewlings of cubs.
The Good Doctor, On Bended Knee

Roaming the capital of Silla, Dr. Rizal finds himself in the midst of a royal procession. Just as a guard attempts to remove him, he catches the sun's glint off a man's magnificent gold and jade crown.
These are a prosperous people to have such finery.
There is a great power embedded in that crown.
Silla Unique Ranged Unit. Has +1 Movement and +3 Bombard Strength. Counts as a Cavalry Unit and ignores Zone of Control.
Tier 1 Silla Unique Ranged Unit. Has +1 Movement and +3 Bombard Strength. Counts as a Cavalry Unit and ignores Zone of Control.
Tier 2 Silla Unique Ranged Unit. Has +1 Movement and +3 Bombard Strength. Counts as a Cavalry Unit and ignores Zone of Control.

Silla Unique Merchant. When you create a trade route receive +5 [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold for the current Relationship Level with the Civilization (does not apply to City-States), on Standard Speed. Minimum 5 [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold.
Gain[icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture equal to 25% of the defeated Unit's strength.
Gain Culture equal to 25% of the defeated Unit's strength.
As Silla, complete an Economic Legacy Path.
As Silla, complete the Emile Bell.
